apd8F5CFE04-122E-441D-A3FD-8C59F34272B7.content:
Share files and other resources (File Sharing, FTP, Xsan)

OS X Server has three services that can help you share file-based resources in your organization.

  • File Sharing service is for sharing files with Mac and Windows computers using their native file sharing protocols (AFP and SMB, respectively) and for managing WebDAV sharing for mobile devices.

    For information on File Sharing service, see this help topic:

    Share files across devices

  • FTP is often used by website developers to transfer files to a web server. If you are setting up your server as a web server and want others to be able to work on content for websites hosted on your server, you should enable FTP service.

    For information on FTP service, see this help topic:

    Provide FTP service

  • Xsan is a high-speed distributed file system. It allows many users to share a pool of files without having to explicitly connect to a server. Xsan only works if all the computers are local to each other on a fibre-channel network.

    Important:

    Xsan service requires a static IP address.

    For information on setting up a static IP address, see this help topic:

    Prepare your Internet connection

    For information on setting up Xsan, see this help topic:

    Share files with Xsan

apd7D270EEE-E142-4C1F-A9EE-AD281A0968C7.content:
DNS records

The following are DNS records used by OS X Server services. Not all records are required for all services.

A (address)

An A record is required. It maps your server’s host name to its IP address. If you have an Internet router, your server has a unique, private IP address on your intranet, but on the Internet it uses the router’s public IP address.

PTR (pointer)

A PTR record is required. It provides a reverse lookup by mapping the server’s IP address to its host name. If you have an Internet router, your server has a unique, private IP address on your intranet, but on the Internet it uses the router’s public IP address.

MX (mail exchange)

If your server provides Mail service, the optional MX record specifies that your server is a mail server for your domain. An MX record lets users have an email address such as mchen@example.com. Without an MX record, email addresses must include your server’s full host name (for example, mchen@server.example.com).

CNAME (alias)

One or more optional CNAME records provide convenient access to services your server provides, such as mail.example.com and www.example.com.

SRV for Contacts service

If your server provides Contacts service, you can add an optional SRV record for Contacts service’s CardDAV protocol.

  • If you have an SSL certificate for Contacts service, add a record that maps _carddavs._tcp for port 8443 to your server’s host name. For example:
    _carddavs._tcp 86400 IN SRV 0 1 8443 server.example.com
  • If you don’t have an SSL certificate for Contacts service, add a record that maps _carddav._tcp for port 8008 to your server’s host name. For example:
    _carddav._tcp 86400 IN SRV 0 1 8008 server.example.com

SRV for Calendar service

If your server provides Calendar service, you can add an optional SRV record for Calendar service’s CalDAV protocol.

  • If you have an SSL certificate for Calendar service, you can add an optional record that maps _carddavs._tcp for port 8443 to your server’s host name. For example:
    _caldavs._tcp 86400 IN SRV 0 1 8443 server.example.com
  • If you don’t have an SSL certificate for Calendar service, add a record that maps _caldav._tcp for port 8008 to your server’s host name. For example:
    _caldav._tcp 86400 IN SRV 0 1 8008 server.example.com

SRV (service locator) for Messages service

If your server provides Messages instant messaging service, you can add two optional SRV (service locator) records for Messages server’s XMPP (Jabber) protocol.

  • One record controls connections between your server and other XMPP servers. It maps _xmpp-server._tcp for port 5269 to your server’s host name. For example:
    _xmpp-server._tcp 86400 IN SRV 0 1 5269 server.example.com
  • Another record controls Messages and other XMPP client connections to your server. It maps _xmpp-client._tcp for port 5222 to your server’s host name. For example:
    _xmpp-client._tcp 86400 IN SRV 0 1 5222 server.example.com

These SRV records let users have a Messages address such as mchen@example.com. Without these SRV records, Messages addresses must include your server’s full host name (for example, mchen@server.example.com).

apd582A7C17-EE14-454E-952F-02B3A13F5812.content:
Secure your server

When considering server security, often the primary issue is the users who have access to your server and what they have access to. A server is primarily accessed over the network, so another key issue is knowing that the server someone is connecting to is the one they think it is. The first step in ensuring your server is secure is to use what are known as "certificates." As a server administrator, you need to understand a little bit about certificates.

About certificates

A certificate is an electronic document that contains identification information (name, organization, email address, and so on). This is referred to as the “Public Key.” Certificates can either be digitally signed by a Certificate Authority (CA), which means they are issued by some trusted source and considered valid because that source vouches for them, or they can be self-signed. The latter certficate is simply trusting in the integrity of your own organization. If the only people that are using your server are within your organization and accessing your server from your network, then a self-signed certificate is OK. If people are accessing your server from outside of your network, then you probably want to get a trusted certificate signed by a CA.

A certificate is a file in a specified format (OS X Server uses the x.509 format) that contains:
  • The public key half of a public-private key pair
  • The key user’s identity information, such as a person’s name and contact information
  • A validity period (how long the certificate can be trusted to be accurate)
  • The URL of someone with the power to revoke the certificate (its revocation center)
  • The digital signature of a CA, or the key user

Manage certificates

When you install OS X Server, it generates a default certificate that is optionally used by services. This is a self-signed certificate based on your network configuration at the time you set up your server. You can view this certificate by selecting Certificates in the Server app's sidebar.

You manage certificates in the Certificates pane of the Server app and in some of its service panels.

The following Help topics discuss specific aspects of managing certificates:
  • View installed certificates
  • Assign certificates to specific services
  • Obtain a trusted certificate
  • Import a certificate identity

Provide network infrastructure (DHCP, DNS, VPN)

OS X Server includes industry-standard services you can use to manage your local network.

These services are advanced services that are usually provided by your ISP or IT department. Do not enable these services unless you are sure that you need them and that you will not interfere with other network services providing similar services.
Important: These services require a static IP address and that DNS is configured properly.

For more information about these network services, see this help topic:

Prepare your Internet connection

  • DHCP service lets you distribute your assigned IP addresses to other computers and devices.

    For information on DHCP service, see this help topic:

    Provide IP addresses with DHCP

  • DNS service establishes your computer as a DNS server on your local network and possibly the Internet.

    For information on DNS service, see this help topic:

    Provide DNS service

  • VPN service lets you build a secure network to access your internal computers and resources from an external network.

    For information on VPN service, see this help topic:

    Secure remote access with VPN

apd92B154BE-7FB5-41DC-B726-0252B02D3EA5.content:
OS X Server for small business

A Mac with OS X Server installed can provide all the services needed by computer and mobile device users in a small business.

In the following illustration of OS X Server in a small business, the server and the users’ computers are all connected to an intranet that shares a DSL or cable Internet connection. The Internet connection is shared through a router, which can be an AirPort Extreme Base Station (802.11n), a Time Capsule, or a router from your ISP or a computer retailer.



The router connects to the Internet through a DSL modem or cable modem and connects to the intranet to share the Internet connection with the server and the users’ computers. The server and some of the users’ computers have wired connections to the intranet, and other users’ computers connect to the intranet wirelessly through the Wi-Fi router. The server and the users’ computers get their network addresses from the router’s DHCP server. They get DNS name service from the ISP.

The router also protects the server and the users’ computers against malicious attacks from the Internet by blocking communications that originate outside the intranet. However, the router is configured to allow incoming communications for some services. For example, the router allows the server’s Mail service to receive email from outside the intranet, and Messages service can receive instant messaging invitations from Google Talk users via the Internet. All the wired and wireless computers and mobile devices on the intranet get services from the server.

The server provides user and group accounts, shared folders, server-based contact lists, shared calendars, instant messaging, and wikis with web calendars and blogs. The ISP doesn’t provide enough email addresses for everyone in the organization, so the server provides email addresses and Mail service.

Users with OS X use Time Machine to back up their Mac computers to an external hard drive (not shown) attached to the server.

Some users have their portable computers, home computers, and mobile devices set up to connect to the server’s VPN via the Internet. VPN gives them secure remote access, while traveling or working at home, to all the services that the server provides on the intranet. iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch users can check wikis and blogs while roaming.

apdA4189F88-1CC1-4F58-ADF0-802D1C4608DE.content:
Prepare your Internet connection

To access your server, users need to know where it is on the Internet.

Obtain an IP address

Before setting up a server, you should obtain a dedicated IP address for it.
You need the following:
  • An IP address. Depending on the services you want to provide, you need a dedicated (or static) IP address.
  • A domain name. IP addresses aren't easy for people to remember, so there's a protocol called DNS that allows regular words to mapped to IP addresses. Register a domain name you like, and then map it through a DNS service.
This IP address has two charactaristics that are especially important to consider when configuring your computer as a server.
  1. Is the IP address static or dynamic?
  2. Is it world-routable?
A dynamic address is one that changes at some set interval. Today it could be one number and tomorrow another. It may even change every few hours. You may want to request a static IP Address from your internet provider. This allows users to always be able to get to your server using that number, or when you have configured DNS, the hostname.

A static address is not enough, it must also be a world-routable IP address if you want users outside of your local network to be able to find it. IP Addresses that are not world-routable usually begin with either the number 10 or the number 169. If you have one of these numbers, you need to configure your router to assign a static IP address to your server.

Register the server’s Internet host name

To allow users to access the server by using its host name on the Internet, you must register the server’s host name.

  • Obtain an Internet domain name, such as example.com.

    If you don’t already have a domain name, you can purchase one from a public domain name registrar. For information about domain name registrars, search the web.

  • Register a unique host name for this server, such as server.example.com, with your domain name registrar.

    If your organization has a computer support group, request a host name from them. Otherwise, work with the domain name registrar where you obtained your domain name to assign a host name.

Set appropriate DNS records

Before you set up your server, have your DNS server administrator add records for your server to a DNS server. If your organization has a computer support group, ask if they host DNS servers. Otherwise, your DNS registrar might provide DNS hosting service, or you can search the web for a provider. After these records are added, users can access your server by using its host name, such as server.mycompany.com.
Users can use your server’s host name on your intranet if the DNS server administrator for your intranet adds DNS records for your server. If your intranet doesn’t have a DNS server, users can access your server by using its local hostname, such as server.local. Users can use your server’s host name on the Internet if a DNS hosting service adds the records described below to its DNS servers. These records must point your server’s host name to the public IP address of your Internet router, if you have one. The DNS registrar you obtained a domain name from might provide DNS hosting service, or you can search the web for a provider.

Test forward and reverse DNS

If you have set up DNS, make sure everything works properly with DNS, test that the mapping from numbers to words and from words to numbers both work.
The whole DNS system uses what are called “forward” and “reverse” DNS lookups. Forward lookup uses a domain name to find the IP address; reverse lookup uses an IP address to lookup the domain name. Test these before you enable services. If either of these don't work, you may need to retrace your steps to this point or work with your Internet provider to deterimine why these aren't working.
  1. Open the Network Utility app (located in the Other folder in Launchpad).
  2. Select Lookup.
  3. For the forward lookup, type in your domain name, and then click Lookup.
  4. For the reverse lookup, type the IP address, and then click Lookup.
The lower part of the window has a scrolling window where you can see the results. At the bottom of that window there should be a section of text that begins with, ";; ANSWER SECTION:." For a forward lookup, the first result should look something like:
Your_Domain_Name.com.	3600	IN	A	Your_IP_Address
This means that the A record in DNS for Your_Domain_Name does indeed point to Your_IP_Address.
Similarly, for a reverse lookup you should see something like: 
Your_IP_Address_Reversed.in-addr.arpa. 3600	IN	PTR	Your_Domain_Name.
This time, your IP address is in reverse order, which means there is a DNS PTR record for your IP address that points to your domain name. There may be more information in the message depending on your network setup, but if you don't see clearly your domain name and your IP address you probably want to seek further assistance.

If forward and reverse DNS do not work, one tool that won't work is Kerberos. Kerberos is one of the optional security mechanisms used by many services in OS X Server (and required for some like Profile Manager), so it is very important that forward and reverse DNS work properly.

apd305F8D97-FE13-4B2E-9C75-2C2C22F03CD9.content:
Set up user accounts

User accounts let users gain access to services provided by the server. A user account contains the information needed to prove the user’s identity for services that require authentication, and a centeral place to store a user’s contact information and other data.

You add user accounts in the Users pane of the Server app by:

  • Creating accounts
  • Using existing accounts, if your organization has a network account server (also known as a directory server) that your server is connected to
  • Importing from a file

The Users pane of the Server app lists local user accounts (including user accounts created in System Preferences), network accounts stored in your server’s network account server, and imported user accounts.

Determine who will have accounts on your server

Once you complete basic server setup, you have to determine the services users will have access to. The first step is to build a list of users. Anybody that has a need for individual access to the following services should get an account:
  • Calendar
  • File Sharing
  • FTP
  • Mail
  • Messages
  • Profile Manager
  • Time Machine
  • Wiki

Usually you set up user accounts for individuals, but in some cases you might want to set up an account for a certain role or position that could be shared by multiple people. Generally though, you can set up accounts for individuals and then use groups to assign privileges to certain groups of people.

Group users into groups

Once you have a list of users, you can group them. There are two primary ways to group people:
  • Prexisting organizational groups
  • Intended access privileges

An organizational group might be something like, “Science teachers,” or, “3rd floor residents,” or “Non-Commissioned Officers.” These would be groups that exist outside of any particular plan of how you might later manage them using the Server app. These are groups that exist already in your organization. They give you a foundation to easily manage collections of people later as your use of OS X Server grows. Then, as you begin thinking about individual services you will use, you should consider other groups that are related to OS X Server. These groups might be things like, “Server Administrators,” or “Wiki Authors.”

Groups will be the primary way that you assign rights and responsibilities on your server. Consequently, they will also be the primary way that you make sure that information is secure on your server.

You can always add people to or remove them from groups and even make groups of groups. So don't worry if you don't get it exactly right the first time.

Decide if users will have network or local accounts

Users with administrator privileges on their Mac computers can create local user accounts using the Users & Groups pane of System Preferences. These local user accounts are stored on the user’s computer. Local user accounts have home folders on the computer and can be used to log in to the computer. Users can’t use their computers’ local user accounts to access the server over the network. Users can use the server’s local user accounts to access the server over the network.

Like users’ Mac computers, your server has local accounts in addition to server accounts and, possibly, imported accounts. Your server’s local accounts can be used to log in to the server, and a local account with administrator privileges can be used to administer the server.

For information about administrator privileges, see this help topic:

About administrator accounts.

Network accounts are stored in your server’s network account server or in a connected network account server. You can use the Server app to enable a network account server on your server. If you don’t enable the network account server, then all accounts you create on the server are stored in the server’s local directory.

There are a few reasons to host network accounts on your server:

  • Your organization has a network account server, also known as a directory server, and you want people to use their existing network accounts with your server. Your server must be a network account server to import users from an existing network account server.
  • You plan to have multiple servers and want each user to have one network account that works with all your servers.
  • You want to use Profile Manager to manage Mac computers with OS X and iOS devices such as iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch.

Types of user accounts

Your server can have its own network accounts or use accounts from an existing network server. You can also import accounts, which stores a synced copy of the network account from another network server on your network server.

Here’s a comparison of the four types of accounts:

FeatureLocal accountsNetwork accounts on your serverNetwork accounts from an existing network serverImported accounts
Where the account is stored:Local directoryLocal network serverAnother network serverAnother network server
Who creates this:A user with an administrator account on the computer using System Preferences, or the Server app if the server’s network account server is disabledYou (a server administrator), using the Server appThe network account server’s administratorThe network account server’s administrator
Membership in network groups:AllowedAllowedAllowedAllowed
System Preferences support:Allows editing (including changing the password), local group membershipCan change passwordCan change passwordCan change password
Local access to server’s services:Full accessFull accessWiki onlyFull access
Remote access to server’s services:Full accessFull accessWiki onlyFull access
Access to group shared folders:Full accessFull accessFull accessFull access
Home folder on server:YesYesNoNo

apdA560CA6D-E835-4BD6-8816-42190F4DD1CC.content:
Manage other computers and iOS devices (Open Directory, Profile Manager, Time Machine)

With OS X Server, you can manage how client computers and devices work within your organization's network. This could include managing what printers, servers, or apps someone has access to, as well as security settings, app preferences, and backing up data.

  • Open Directory provides a way for computers to securely communicate with your server and determines what resources they are allowed to access. Open Direcory is based on industry standard protocols like LDAP and Kerberos to enable interoperability with other directory services in your organization.

    Important:

    Open Directory service requires a static IP address and that forward and reverse DNS resolve properly.

    For more information on these network requirements, see this help topic:

    Prepare your Internet connection

    For information on the Open Directory service, see this help topic:

    Provide Open Directory service

  • Profile Manager service lets you define and load your organization's required settings and preferences onto your user’s computers and iOS devices.

    Important:
    Profile Manager service requires:
    • A static IP address
    • Forward and reverse DNS to resolve properly
    • Your server to be an Open Directory Master
    For more information on these network requirements, see this help topic:

    Prepare your Internet connection

    For information on Profile Manager service, see this help topic:

    Start Profile Manager

  • With Time Machine service, your server can be a network backup destination for Mac computers using Time Machine.

    Important: Time Machine service requires either a static IP address or a domain name that always resolves to your server.

    For more information on setting up a static IP address, see this help topic:

    Prepare your Internet connection

    For information on Time Machine service, see this help topic:

    Provide Time Machine service

apd5B0E80DB-9658-4D8A-9A90-7CBF5455B9BE.content:
OS X Server for workgroups

A Mac with OS X Server installed can provide services to a workgroup, such as a department in a large organization.

In the following illustration of OS X Server in a workgroup, the organization has an IT department that provides DHCP service for assigning network addresses, DNS name service, Mail service, Internet access, and a VPN.



Everyone in the department already has a user account provided by the organization’s network accounts server, so these user accounts have been imported to the department’s server. This means everyone simply uses the user name and password they already know to authenticate for services provided by the department’s server. Those services are set up to use single sign-on authentication with the network account server, allowing users to log in once per session for all departmental services.

The department’s server provides address book, calendar, and instant messaging services that work with the users’ OS X Contacts, Calendar, and Messages apps. The department’s server also provides shared folders and private wikis for groups and projects within the department. Some projects include participants from outside the department. Outside participants use their existing user accounts to authenticate for wiki or shared folder access.

The organization’s servers provide storage for backup, but most users have OS X and prefer to use Time Machine with the external hard drive (not shown) attached to the department’s server.

The department has some Windows users, who use Internet Explorer, Safari, and FireFox to access wikis, web calendars, and blogs. Shared folders appear as mapped drives in their Network Places. They have also set up their PCs to use the department server’s Jabber instant messaging.

apdECE61570-3C80-4E89-B24C-E7988A28ABD8.content:
Set up your server with future growth in mind

With the right planning, OS X Server can serve your needs today and grow with you to accomodate future needs.

With the right planning, OS X Server can provide the services you need today and grow with you to accommodate future needs. When thinking about future growth, there are two questions you should ask yourself before you set up your server:
  • Do I need a host name for the Internet?
  • Do I want local or network user accounts?

For example, if you currently only want to use the Wiki server, you don't need a host name for the Internet or network user accounts. However, if you think you'll want to use Profile Manager in the future, you need to set up a host name for the Internet and set up user accounts to be network accounts. The following table can help you determine what you need for the services you want to provide.

apd299D5A73-D5DA-416D-BA48-EB5104A0DC11.content:
Manage installation and updates of software on Mac Computers (Caching, NetInstall, Software Update)

OS X Server lets you manage installation of OS X versions specific to the needs of your organization as well as to control which Apple software updates are available to the computers on your network.

Important: These services all require either a static IP address or a domain name that always resolves to your server.

For more information on providing these network services, see this help topic:

Prepare your Internet connection

  • Caching service caches a local copy of software available from the Mac App store. This means that after the first time a user on your network downloads a resource it is stored on your local network so that subsequent downloads of that software come from your network and don't use external network bandwidth.

    For information on setting up Caching service, see this help topic:

    Provide a Caching server

  • NetInstall service allows you to deploy specific or even custom OS X installation images that clients on your network can install.

    For information on setting up the NetInstall service, see this help topic:

    Provide NetInstall service

  • Software Update service allows you to manage how you make specific Apple software updates available to client Mac computers on your network.

    For information on setting up the Software Update service, see this help topic:

    Provide Software Update service

apdC08C50C7-0E62-437C-B655-820233EE2F5C.content:
Provide collaborative services (Calendar, Contacts, Messages, Mail, Wiki)

OS X Server includes services that allow you to share information throughout your organization using software tools that people are already familiar with. Enabling these services gives you various ways to communicate and share information and resources with others in your organization across computers and other portable devices.

  • Calendar service gives you online shared calendars. It can be accessed both through a web browser and by calendar programs like the Calendar apps on iOS devices and Mac computers.

    For information on setting up Calendar service, see this help topic:

    Manage shared calendars

  • Messages service allows you to instantly communicate directly with individuals and small groups of people in your organization with text messages, audio or video chats, and direct file transfers.

    For information on setting up Messages service, see this help topic:

    Provide Messages service

  • Email is the heart of communication and collaboration in many organizations. OS X Server Mail service allows you to send and receive email and also provides virus and spam filtering. Clients connect to your Mail server with the email software built into their operating system or mobile devices.

    Important:

    Mail service requires either a static IP address or a domain name that always resolves to your server.

    For more information on these network requirements, see this help topic:

    Prepare your Internet connection

    For information on Mail service, see this help topic:

    Provide email service

  • The Wiki server lets you or anyone you designate in your organization to easily build websites to keep up to date on projects or ideas. You can link to files, other websites, and calendars from a Wiki page. Wiki pages are edited from a web browser on Mac or Windows computers and iOS devices.

    For information on Wiki service, see this help topic:

    Use Wikis
